column1: 51	In round 1
column2: my opponent argued that the death penalty should not be implemented because it is "unfair
column3: kills innocents
column4: and doesn't even serve it's deterrence purpose
column5: and on top of that is is expensive". I will now demonstrate that these claims are invalid.   Firstly
column6: the death penalty is not necessarily unfair. While it is true that innocent people can be wrongly convicted and sentenced to death
column7: there are several safeguards in place to prevent this from occurring. In order to ensure that only guilty people are executed
column8: every death penalty case must undergo a comprehensive review and appeal process. This process involves numerous levels of review
column9: including appeals to higher courts
column10: which provide opportunities to prove innocence or to have a sentence of death commuted to a sentence of life imprisonment. The death penalty is also an effective deterrent against crime. Recent studies have shown that the death penalty can serve as a powerful deterrent to potential criminals as the possibility of execution deters many from committing a crime in the first place. Finally
column11: the death penalty is not as expensive as my opponent suggests. The cost of executing a criminal is far less than the cost of keeping that person in prison for their entire life
column12: as is the case with many death row inmates. In fact
column13: a study conducted by the National Research Council found that the cost of keeping a prisoner in prison for life can be as much as 18 times more expensive than executing the same individual. Thus
column14: the death penalty is not as expensive as my opponent claims.   Furthermore
column15: I would argue that a death penalty that is implemented as a voluntary option for defendants is even more effective in deterring crime and preventing the execution of innocent people. In such a system
column16: defendants will only be able to choose death if they believe that death is the only just punishment for their crime
column17: eliminating the chance that innocent people will be wrongly executed. Additionally
column18: if the defendant knows that he has the option to choose death
column19: he is more likely to think twice before committing a crime as the risk of execution is real and present. As such
column20: a voluntary death penalty would be even more effective in deterring crime and preventing the execution of innocent people than an involuntary death penalty.

column1: 52	First of all I would like to make my "points" as to why I am opposed to the death penalty. 1. The cost of a death penalty case is much higher than the cost of a comparable non-death penalty case due to the need to provide more resources such as specialized medical personnel

column1: 54	The death penalty is an issue that has been debated for centuries
column2: with some arguing that it serves as a deterrent to crime while others claiming that it is an expensive form of vengeance that does not provide any rehabilitation for the convicted. Those in favor of the death penalty argue that it provides justice for the victims and their families and serves as a deterrent to criminal activity. The opposing argument is that it costs more than life in prison and can lead to innocent people being executed.
